title: Silent Reading Assessment & Reading Journal Launch
description: Students begin the year with a silent reading period to assess fluency and comprehension. They set up their reading journal, which will be a year-long companion for recording books read, favorite passages, and new vocabulary.
instructions:
1. Welcome the child to their new Lower Elementary year. Discuss how they are now researchers and explorers.
2. Invite the child to select a book from the classroom library at their reading level.
3. Set a timer for 15 minutes of silent, independent reading.
4. While reading, observe the child's fluency — note whether they subvocalize, track with fingers, or read smoothly.
5. After reading, ask the child to tell you about what they read (retelling for comprehension).
6. Introduce the Reading Journal: a blank notebook where they will record the title, author, date, and a short response for each book.
7. Have the child make their first entry.
8. Discuss reading goals for the year.
materials_needed: Selection of chapter books at various reading levels
Colored pencils for decorating journal cover

slides.heading: Welcome to Lower Elementary!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This slide is like a big welcome banner for our whole school year. It's telling us that we're starting something super exciting called "Lower Elementary," and our reading adventure is just beginning! Think of it like opening a brand new treasure chest full of stories and amazing facts.

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange a selection of 8-10 books on a shelf or table. Have a blank notebook ready for the Reading Journal. Set the timer for 15 minutes.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll need for our reading mission! We have lots of chapter books, which are like adventures waiting to happen, and a special blank notebook called a Reading Journal where we'll keep track of everything. We also have pencils and colored pencils to make our journal extra special, and a timer to help us focus. Go grab these things so we're ready to explore!

slides.text: Welcome your child to their Lower Elementary year. Say: 'This year, you are a researcher and an explorer. You will discover the story of the universe, of life, and of human beings. And it all starts with reading — the most powerful tool a researcher has.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like a secret code from our teacher! It's telling me that this year, I get to be a super smart researcher and explorer, just like someone who discovers new planets or ancient treasures. Reading is the most important tool for that, like a detective needs a magnifying glass to find clues. So, let's get ready to discover amazing things through books!

slides.text: Invite the child to browse the book selection and choose one that interests them. Give them time — choosing a book is an important skill. If they struggle, offer two options and let them pick.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to pick our first adventure! This slide is inviting you to look at all these cool books and choose one that makes you curious. It's okay if it takes a little while to find the perfect one – that's part of being a good explorer! If you're stuck, I can help you pick between two that look exciting.

slides.text: Set the timer for 15 minutes. Say: 'Read silently to yourself. If you come to a word you don't know, try to figure it out from the words around it. We'll talk about the book when you're done.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to dive into a story! This slide tells us to set the timer for 15 minutes and read quietly all by ourselves. When you come to a word that's tricky, try looking at the words around it to see if they give you a clue. We're going to be super readers, and we'll talk about your story when the timer buzzes!

slides.text: After reading, ask: 'Tell me about what you read. What happened? Who are the characters? What do you think will happen next?' Listen carefully for comprehension, sequencing, and vocabulary.
slides.mascot_explanation: After our reading adventure, this slide is asking us to be storytellers! You get to tell me all about the book you just read – who was in it, what happened, and what you think might happen next. This helps us remember all the amazing details and shows how much we understood.

slides.text: Introduce the Reading Journal. Show the child how to set up an entry: Date, Title, Author, Pages Read, and a 2-3 sentence response. Model an entry with a book you have read.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is introducing our super cool Reading Journal! It's a special notebook where we'll be like authors and record every book we read. We'll write down the date, the book's title, who wrote it, and then a few sentences about what we thought of it. I'll show you exactly how to make your very first entry!

slides.prompt: Decorate the cover of your Reading Journal with your name and illustrations of things you love to read about. Then make your first entry for the book you just read. Write at least 2 sentences about what you read.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make our Reading Journal our own! This slide says we get to decorate the cover with our name and drawings of things we love to read about – how fun! Then, we'll use our new journal to write about the book we just finished, telling a few sentences about what happened. You can do this!

slides.text: Share your first journal entry aloud. This journal will grow all year — by June, you'll be amazed at how many books you've read and how your writing has grown!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read silently for 15 minutes? Can they retell what they read with some detail? Can they write a 2-3 sentence response?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! This last slide is celebrating all our hard work. We're going to share what we wrote in our journal, and it's like showing off our explorer's logbook. Think about how many more books we'll read and how much better our writing will get by the end of the year – you're going to be an amazing reader!

parent_notes: This first language lesson serves a dual purpose: it assesses your child's current reading level while establishing the Reading Journal as a year-long practice. In Montessori elementary, children are expected to read independently for extended periods. If 15 minutes is too long, start with 10 and build up. The key is that the child CHOOSES their book — intrinsic motivation is central to Montessori. Good chapter book series for this age: Magic Tree House, Junie B. Jones, Cam Jansen, Mercy Watson, The Boxcar Children. Don't correct during silent reading; note struggles for later phonics or vocabulary work. The Reading Journal should feel like THEIR book, not a chore — let them decorate it however they wish.

title: Place Value Review with the Stamp Game (4-Digit Numbers)
description: Students review place value concepts using the Montessori stamp game, building and reading 4-digit numbers. This lesson confirms mastery of the decimal system from primary and extends to thousands.
instructions:
1. Lay out the stamp game on a work mat.
2. Review the color-coding: green units, blue tens, red hundreds, green thousands.
3. Build a 4-digit number together (e.g., 3,247) by placing stamps in each column.
4. Have the child read the number aloud.
5. Practice exchanging: show that 10 unit stamps = 1 ten stamp, 10 tens = 1 hundred, 10 hundreds = 1 thousand.
6. Build 5 more numbers of increasing complexity.
7. Play the 'secret number' game — write a number on paper, child builds it.
8. Reverse: child builds a number, parent reads it.
materials_needed: Number cards (1-9 for each place value)

slides.heading: Place Value Review
slides.subheading: Building Big Numbers with the Stamp Game
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our math adventure today! It tells us we're going to be reviewing how numbers are built using something called place value, and we'll use special stamps to make big, four-digit numbers. Get ready to build!

items: Stamp game (units, tens, hundreds, thousands stamps)
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the stamp game on the mat with stamps sorted by place value. Have paper and pencil ready for recording numbers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for building numbers! We need the stamp game, which has little stamps for ones, tens, hundreds, and thousands – see how they have different colors? We also need a big mat to spread everything out on, and paper and a pencil for writing. Go grab those with a grown-up so we can start building!

slides.text: Review the stamps. Hold up each type: 'Remember these from Primary? Green is units — ones. Blue is tens. Red is hundreds. And now we'll use thousands — green again, but with a different symbol.' Point out the hierarchy: units, tens, hundreds, thousands.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is reminding us about our special stamps. Remember how the green ones are just plain old ones, like counting fingers? Then the blue ones are for groups of ten, the red ones for groups of one hundred, and now we have new green ones for groups of one thousand! It's like building with blocks, where each block is worth more than the one before it.

slides.text: Say: 'Let's build the number 3,247.' Start from the thousands: place 3 thousand stamps, then 2 hundred stamps, then 4 ten stamps, then 7 unit stamps. Read aloud: 'Three thousand, two hundred, forty-seven.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to build our first big number: 3,247! We'll start with the biggest part, the thousands, and put down 3 of those green thousand stamps. Then we'll add 2 red hundred stamps, 4 blue ten stamps, and finally 7 little green unit stamps. When we put them all together, we can read it as "three thousand, two hundred, forty-seven."

slides.text: Demonstrate exchanging: 'What happens if I have 10 unit stamps? Watch — I can trade them for 1 ten stamp.' Count out 10 units, replace with 1 ten. Repeat for tens to hundreds.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like a magic trick with numbers! We're going to see how we can trade stamps. If we have 10 of the tiny green unit stamps, we can trade them all in for just one blue ten stamp, because 10 ones make a ten! We can do the same thing with tens and hundreds – it shows us how numbers are organized.

slides.text: Write a 'secret number' on paper (e.g., 1,586). Fold it and pass it to the child. They unfold, read it, and build it with stamps. Check together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time for a super fun guessing game! I'm going to write a secret number down on this paper, like maybe 1,586. Then I'll fold it up and give it to you. Your job is to unfold it, read the number, and then use your stamps to build it exactly on the mat. We'll check together to see if you got it right!

slides.prompt:
Build these numbers with your stamps, then write each one on paper:
1. 4,321
2. 2,058 (notice the zero — no tens!)
3. 7,600
4. 1,111
5. 9,999 (the biggest 4-digit number!)
Then create 3 secret numbers for your parent to read.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you get to build some awesome numbers now! You'll build 4,321, then 2,058 – watch out for that zero, it means there are no tens! Then you'll build 7,600, 1,111, and the biggest number possible with four digits, 9,999. After that, you get to be the secret keeper and make up three secret numbers for a grown-up to build.

slides.text: You just built numbers all the way to 9,999! This week we'll use these stamps to do addition with really big numbers.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build any 4-digit number correctly with stamps? Can they read 4-digit numbers including those with zeros (e.g., 3,047)?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You built numbers all the way up to 9,999 with those stamps, which is amazing! We learned how each stamp has its own special place and how they all add up to make big numbers. This is going to be super helpful for when we start adding really big numbers together next time!

parent_notes: The stamp game is the bridge between concrete (golden beads) and abstract (paper math). Your child used it in primary for 2-3 digit operations. Now we extend to 4 digits and will soon use the bead frame, which is even more abstract. The key concept is that each column is 10x the previous one. If your child breezes through this, great — it means primary gave them a solid foundation. If they struggle with 4-digit numbers, spend extra time here before moving to operations. The 'zero placeholder' concept (like 3,047 having no hundreds... wait, it has zero tens) is particularly important and often tricky.

title: The First Great Lesson: God Who Has No Hands (Part 1)
description: The First Great Lesson is the cornerstone of Montessori elementary education. This dramatic, awe-inspiring story tells of the creation of the universe — from the Big Bang through the formation of stars, galaxies, and our solar system. This is Part 1: the birth of the universe and the laws that govern matter.
instructions:
1. Prepare the room: dim lights, light a candle. This lesson should feel SPECIAL.
2. Gather materials for the demonstrations.
3. Tell the story dramatically — this is a STORY, not a lecture.
4. Perform each demonstration at the right moment in the story.
5. Allow silence and wonder after each demonstration.
6. End with the formation of Earth.
7. Allow the child to ask questions and discuss.
8. Offer follow-up work: drawing, writing, or research.
materials_needed: Chart or poster of the universe timeline

slides.heading: The First Great Lesson
slides.subheading: God Who Has No Hands — The Story of the Universe
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a really exciting book! It tells us that we're about to hear "The First Great Lesson," which is the super special story of how everything in the whole universe came to be, starting from the very beginning.

items: Tray of water, food coloring, oil
slides.setup_instructions: Cover the table with a dark cloth. Have all demonstration materials ready but hidden under the cloth or behind you. Light the candle. Dim the room lights. This lesson should feel ceremonial and awe-inspiring.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things! We've got a black balloon with glitter inside to pretend it's the start of everything, some water and food coloring to show how things mix, a candle to represent a star, and an ice cube for when things get cold. You'll also see a long chart that shows the order of everything that happened, and a dark cloth to make our table look like outer space. We need all these special things to help tell the amazing story!

slides.text: Begin with wonder: 'Today I'm going to tell you the most amazing story ever told. It's the story of how EVERYTHING began — the stars, the Earth, the oceans, and eventually... you. Are you ready?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, get ready for the most amazing story ever! The person telling the story is going to ask if you're ready to hear about how absolutely everything started – the stars, our planet Earth, and even you. Just listen closely and get excited for the adventure!

slides.text: Tell the story: 'In the beginning, there was nothing. No light, no sound, no air. Just darkness and a tiny, tiny point of energy — smaller than a grain of sand. And then... BANG!' (Pop the balloon with glitter inside — gold glitter scatters like stars.) 'The universe EXPLODED into being! Particles of matter flew in every direction, and they began to follow RULES — laws that no one wrote down, but that every particle obeyed.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine a time when there was absolutely nothing – no light, no sound, nothing at all. Then, with a giant *BANG*, the whole universe burst into existence, like this balloon popping and sending glitter everywhere like tiny stars! All these little bits of matter started flying and following invisible rules, kind of like how you follow the rules of a game.

slides.text: Demonstrate the laws of matter: Drop food coloring into water — 'Liquids mix and spread.' Drop oil into the same water — 'But some things DON'T mix. Oil follows its own law — it stays separate.' Show the ice cube — 'And when things get cold enough, they change. Liquid becomes solid. These are the laws the particles followed.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to see those invisible rules in action! See how the food coloring spreads out in the water? That shows how some things mix together, but then the oil stays separate, showing that not everything mixes the same way. And when things get really cold, like this ice cube, they can change from liquid to solid, proving that everything in the universe follows special laws.

slides.text: Continue the story: 'Over billions of years, the particles gathered into enormous clouds of gas and dust. Gravity pulled them together — tighter and tighter — until they became so hot they burst into light. STARS were born!' Point to the candle flame. 'Stars are like this flame, but millions of times bigger and hotter.'
slides.mascot_explanation: After all those tiny bits of matter flew apart, they started to come together over a super, super long time, pulled by something called gravity. They got squished together so much that they became incredibly hot and burst into light, making stars! That candle flame is like a tiny, tiny version of a giant star.

slides.text: Conclude Part 1: 'Some stars exploded and their dust made NEW stars, with planets circling around them. One of those stars was our Sun. And one of those planets... was Earth. But Earth was not yet ready for life. It was a ball of fire and rock. Next time, we'll learn what happened to make Earth a home for living things.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, after billions of years, some stars exploded and their leftover dust came together to make new stars, and planets started spinning around them. One of those stars was our very own Sun, and one of those planets was Earth! But at first, Earth was just a hot, fiery rock, not a place where we could live yet.

slides.prompt:
Choose your follow-up work:
1. Draw the story of the universe from the Big Bang to the formation of Earth
2. Write about what surprised you most in the story
3. Begin researching: How big IS the universe? How old is it? Write 3 facts you discover.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to choose how you want to remember this incredible story! You can draw a picture showing everything from the Big Bang to the Earth being made, or you can write down what surprised you the most. Or, you could become a space detective and research how big the universe is and how old it is – how exciting!

slides.text: You just heard the story of how the entire universe was created — 13.8 billion years of history! Everything in the universe follows laws. Next time, we'll continue with how Earth became a special place.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the basic sequence: Big Bang, particles, laws of matter, stars forming, solar system forming? Are they asking questions and showing wonder?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you just learned how the entire universe was created, from a tiny point to all the stars and planets we see today! You saw how everything follows special rules, and how our own Earth was formed. Next time, we'll discover how our planet turned into a cozy home for all of us.

parent_notes: THIS IS THE MOST IMPORTANT LESSON IN MONTESSORI ELEMENTARY. The First Great Lesson sets the tone for the entire year and the entire elementary experience. It must be told dramatically, with awe and reverence. Maria Montessori called it 'God Who Has No Hands' because the laws of nature work without anyone directing them — particles obey laws of attraction, repulsion, and transformation on their own. You don't need to be religious to tell this story; the 'God' in the title refers to the mystery and order of the universe. The demonstrations are key — children this age need to SEE the principles, not just hear about them. Practice the demos beforehand. The balloon-pop is dramatic and memorable. The food coloring and oil demonstrate that matter follows laws. This lesson sparks months of follow-up research in science, geography, and history. Don't rush it. Let the child sit in wonder.

title: Our Solar System — A Cosmic Address
description: Building directly on the First Great Lesson, students explore our solar system as the 'neighborhood' in which Earth formed. They learn the order of the planets, their relative sizes, and begin to understand Earth's special place in the cosmos.
instructions:
1. Connect to the Great Lesson: 'Remember how the universe formed stars, and stars formed solar systems? Let's zoom in on OUR solar system.'
2. Present the solar system chart or model.
3. Name each planet in order, with a key fact about each.
4. Use the scale model activity to understand relative sizes.
5. Discuss what makes Earth special (distance from sun, water, atmosphere).
6. Have the child create a solar system booklet.
materials_needed: Fruits/balls of different sizes for scale model

slides.heading: Our Solar System
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure today! It's showing us that we're going to learn all about our "Solar System," which is like our very own neighborhood in space, and it tells us that Earth is a special part of that neighborhood.

items: Scale model items (watermelon=Jupiter, grapefruit=Saturn, apple=Uranus/Neptune, cherry=Earth, peppercorn=Mercury, grape=Venus/Mars)
slides.setup_instructions: Hang or lay out the solar system chart. Have scale model fruits/objects ready. Prepare the blank booklet by folding and stapling paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the cool things we need to make our solar system adventure happen! We've got a chart that shows all the planets, and then we have different sized fruits and balls that will help us pretend to be the planets so we can see how big or small they are compared to each other. We also have paper and crayons to make our own planet book!

slides.text: Connect to the Great Lesson: 'Yesterday we learned how the universe began and how our Sun was born from a cloud of gas and dust. But the Sun didn't form alone — leftover dust and gas swirled around it and became PLANETS. Eight planets, all orbiting our Sun. Together, they make up our Solar System.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember yesterday how we talked about the whole universe being made? Well, this step reminds us that our Sun was born from that, and all the leftover bits and pieces swirled around to make our planet family, called the Solar System. So, we're zooming in from the giant universe to our own special corner of space!

slides.text: Present each planet in order, using the chart. Give one memorable fact: Mercury (closest, very hot/cold), Venus (hottest, spins backward), Earth (water!), Mars (red, has a huge volcano), Jupiter (biggest, Great Red Spot), Saturn (beautiful rings), Uranus (tilted on its side), Neptune (farthest, windiest).
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we get to meet all of our planet neighbors! We're going to look at the chart and learn the name of each planet, starting with the one closest to the Sun, and I'll tell you a super interesting fact about each one, like which is the biggest or which one has amazing rings!

slides.text: Scale model: 'Let's see how big the planets really are compared to each other.' Use the fruit/ball comparisons. Place them in a line. 'Look how tiny Earth is compared to Jupiter! And the Sun would be as big as a beach ball!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a super fun part – we're going to use these fruits and balls to see how HUGE some planets are compared to others. Imagine the watermelon is Jupiter, the biggest planet, and then look at the tiny cherry that's supposed to be our Earth – it really helps you see how different they are in size!

slides.text: Ask the child: 'What makes Earth special? Why can WE live here but not on Mercury or Jupiter?' Guide discussion toward: distance from sun (not too hot, not too cold), water in liquid form, atmosphere with oxygen. 'Earth is in the habitable zone — the Goldilocks zone!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like a detective mission for Earth! It's asking us to think really hard about why we can live here on Earth, but maybe not on other planets. We'll talk about how Earth is just the right distance from the Sun, has water for swimming, and air that we can breathe!

slides.prompt: Create your Solar System Booklet: one page for each planet. Draw the planet, write its name, and include 2-3 facts. The cover page is 'Our Solar System by [your name].' Use your reference book and chart for information.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to get creative and build your very own solar system book! You'll get to draw each planet on its own page, write its name, and add some cool facts you learned, just like a real scientist documenting their discoveries. Make sure to put your name on the cover!

slides.text: You now know your cosmic address: Universe > Milky Way Galaxy > Solar System > Earth. We live on the third planet from the Sun, in the habitable zone — the perfect place for life!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name the 8 planets in order? Can they explain what makes Earth special for life?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You just learned that we live in an amazing place called Earth, which is the third planet from our Sun, in a super special spot that’s just right for us. You can even tell people our cosmic address: Universe, Milky Way Galaxy, Solar System, and Earth!

parent_notes: This geography lesson flows directly from the First Great Lesson, which is exactly how Montessori elementary works — the Great Lessons are the trunk of the tree, and all subjects branch from them. The solar system connects to the story of how Earth formed. The scale model is important because children cannot grasp cosmic distances from pictures alone. If you can, do this outdoors: place the 'Sun' (a beach ball) at one end of a field and walk the planets out to scale — Mercury would be about 10 paces away, but Neptune would be nearly 1,000! This visceral experience of scale is unforgettable. The 'cosmic address' concept helps children feel connected to the universe — a core Montessori elementary goal called 'cosmic education.'

title: Read-Aloud: 'Born With a Bang' by Jennifer Morgan (Chapter 1)
description: Begin the year with this beautiful picture book that tells the scientific story of the Big Bang in narrative form, perfectly complementing the First Great Lesson. The read-aloud program builds listening comprehension, vocabulary, and a love of literature.
instructions:
1. Introduce the book and author.
2. Discuss the cover: 'What do you think this book is about?'
3. Read Chapter 1 aloud with expression and drama.
4. Pause at key moments to ask prediction questions.
5. After reading, discuss connections to the First Great Lesson.
6. Introduce 3 vocabulary words from the reading.
7. Have the child respond in their reading journal.
materials_needed: 'Born With a Bang' by Jennifer Morgan (or similar Big Bang book for children)

slides.heading: Read-Aloud Time
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us the title of our special reading time today. It tells us we're going to read a book called 'Born With a Bang,' and we're starting with the very first chapter. This is like the introduction to a cool adventure story!

items: 'Born With a Bang' by Jennifer Morgan (or 'The Story of the Universe' or similar)
slides.setup_instructions: Choose a comfortable reading spot — a couch, reading nook, or blanket on the floor. Have the book ready. If you don't have this specific title, any quality children's book about the Big Bang or universe creation works.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the things we need for our reading adventure! We need the book 'Born With a Bang,' which tells the story of how everything started. We also need our reading journal and a pencil to write down our thoughts, and a dictionary to help us learn new words. Make sure you have these ready, maybe ask a grown-up to help you find them!

slides.text: Show the cover. Ask: 'What do you see? What do you think this book will be about? How does the title connect to what we learned in the First Great Lesson?' Let the child make predictions.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here on the screen, you see the cover of our book. Take a good look at it! What pictures do you see? What do you think this story might be about, just by looking at the cover and thinking about the title? How does it remind you of the big story about how everything began that we learned before?

slides.text: Read the first chapter (or first 10-15 pages) aloud. Use a dramatic, engaging voice. Pause at exciting moments: 'What do you think happens next?' This builds prediction skills.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the exciting part – listening to the story! I'm going to read the first chapter of 'Born With a Bang' out loud to you, and I'll try to make it super fun and dramatic. As I read, I'll stop sometimes to ask you what you think might happen next, like a detective trying to figure out a mystery!

slides.text: After reading, discuss: 'How is this story similar to the First Great Lesson we heard? How is it different? What new information did you learn from this book that wasn't in our lesson?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is asking us to think like scientists and story detectives! After we finish reading, we'll talk about how the story we just heard is like the First Great Lesson we learned, and maybe how it's a little different. It's important to see how different stories can teach us similar things!

slides.text: Choose 3 vocabulary words from the reading (e.g., 'universe,' 'particles,' 'gravity'). Write each on a card. Discuss the meaning. Look one up in the dictionary together. Use each in a sentence.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to pick three cool new words from the story today, like 'universe' or 'particles.' We'll write them down, talk about what they mean, maybe even look one up in the dictionary together to become word experts! Then, we'll practice using them in sentences, just like real authors do.

slides.prompt:
In your reading journal, write today's entry:
- Title and Author
- 3 new vocabulary words and their meanings
- Draw your favorite scene from the reading
- Write 2-3 sentences: What was the most interesting part and why?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to be the author! In your reading journal, you'll write down the book's title and author, the new words we learned and what they mean, and draw a picture of your favorite part. Then, you'll write a couple of sentences about what you thought was the most interesting thing and why.

slides.text: We'll continue this book throughout the week. Great readers think about what they read and make connections to what they already know — just like you did today!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the main events from the reading? Can they make connections between the book and the First Great Lesson? Can they use at least 2 of the new vocabulary words?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job with our reading today! We read a story, learned new words, and thought about how it connects to our other lessons. You're becoming a super thinker and reader, just like a real scientist exploring new ideas!

parent_notes: Read-aloud time is sacred in Montessori elementary. Even though your child can read independently, being read TO builds listening comprehension, vocabulary, and a shared literary experience. Choose a comfortable spot and make it cozy. The key pedagogical move here is CONNECTING the read-aloud to the Great Lesson — this shows the child that knowledge is interconnected, not isolated in subject silos. 'Born With a Bang' by Jennifer Morgan is specifically written to complement the Montessori First Great Lesson, but any quality science narrative about the universe will work. Alternatives: 'The Story of Everything' by Neal Layton, 'Older Than the Stars' by Karen Fox, or 'On the Day You Begin' for a more personal cosmic connection. The vocabulary work builds word consciousness — the habit of noticing and learning new words.

title: Grammar Review: The Noun Family (Article, Adjective, Noun)
description: Using Montessori grammar symbols, students review the noun family — the large black triangle (noun), the small light blue triangle (article), and the medium dark blue triangle (adjective). They practice identifying these parts of speech in sentences using the grammar symbol stamps.
instructions:
1. Present the grammar symbols: large black triangle = noun, small light blue triangle = article, medium dark blue triangle = adjective.
2. Review what each part of speech does.
3. Write sentences on sentence strips.
4. Have the child place grammar symbols above each word.
5. Practice with 8-10 sentences of increasing complexity.
6. Introduce the grammar box exercise.
materials_needed: Grammar symbol stamps or cutouts (black triangle, light blue triangle, dark blue triangle)
Sentence strips or paper cut into strips

slides.heading: The Noun Family
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our grammar adventure! It's introducing us to something super important called the "Noun Family," and we're going to learn about its three main members: the article, the adjective, and the noun itself.

items: Grammar symbols (triangles: large black, small light blue, medium dark blue)
Grammar box cards or printed sentences
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 10 sentence strips with simple sentences (e.g., 'The tall tree,' 'A red ball,' 'The beautiful, ancient castle'). Have grammar symbols ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need our special tools for our grammar work! See those triangles? We've got a big black one, a small light blue one, and a medium dark blue one. We'll also need some paper strips with sentences on them, pencils, and a special box with cards. Make sure you have all these things ready, maybe ask a grown-up to help you find them!

slides.text: Present the three symbols. Hold up the large black triangle: 'This represents the NOUN — a naming word. It names a person, place, thing, or idea. It's the biggest triangle because nouns are the foundation of every sentence.' Examples: dog, school, happiness.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to meet the first member of our Noun Family – the NOUN! This big black triangle is for words that name people (like *teacher*), places (like *park*), or things (like *ball*). Nouns are like the main stars of our sentences, and that's why this triangle is the biggest!

slides.text: Hold up the small light blue triangle: 'This is the ARTICLE. Articles are tiny words that come before nouns: a, an, the. They're the smallest triangle because they're small but important — they tell us if we mean a specific thing (THE dog) or any thing (A dog).'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next up is the ARTICLE! This little light blue triangle is for super small words like 'a,' 'an,' and 'the.' Think of them as tiny helpers that tell us if we're talking about one specific thing or just any old thing, kind of like pointing to something special.

slides.text: Hold up the medium dark blue triangle: 'This is the ADJECTIVE. Adjectives DESCRIBE nouns. They tell us what kind, how many, or which one. Big, red, three, beautiful — all adjectives.' Show how the adjective triangle sits next to the noun triangle: 'The adjective is the noun's helper.'
slides.mascot_explanation: And here's the ADJECTIVE! This medium dark blue triangle is for words that describe the noun, like telling us if it's *big*, *red*, or *happy*. Adjectives are like the noun's best friend, giving us more details about what the noun is like.

slides.text: Model with a sentence strip: 'The tall tree.' Place the small light blue triangle over 'The,' the medium dark blue triangle over 'tall,' and the large black triangle over 'tree.' Read it while pointing to each symbol.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to see how the Noun Family works together! We're going to take a sentence, like "The tall tree," and put the right triangle symbol above each word. The little light blue triangle goes over "The," the medium dark blue triangle goes over "tall," and the big black triangle goes over "tree" because "tree" is our noun!

slides.prompt:
Parse these sentences by placing grammar symbols above each word:
1. The big dog
2. A small, gray kitten
3. The ancient, mysterious castle
4. Three beautiful flowers
5. An enormous, golden sun
Then write 5 of your own noun phrases with at least one adjective each.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the grammar detective! You'll look at sentences like "The big dog" and put the correct triangle symbol above each word. Then, you'll get to make up your own sentences with articles, adjectives, and nouns. You've got this!

slides.text: The noun family works as a team: the article introduces, the adjective describes, and the noun names. Tomorrow we'll add more parts of speech!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly identify articles, adjectives, and nouns in a phrase? Can they write their own noun phrases with correct article-adjective-noun structure?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job with the Noun Family today! You learned how articles introduce, adjectives describe, and nouns name things, and how they all work together like a super team. Aren't you excited to learn about even more word families tomorrow?

parent_notes: Montessori grammar uses a brilliant system of geometric symbols to make abstract grammar concepts concrete and visual. The triangle family represents the noun family — all triangles, but different sizes and colors. This is a REVIEW from primary, where children were introduced to the first 3-4 parts of speech. In Lower Elementary, we deepen understanding and work toward all 8 parts of speech. The physical act of placing symbols above words makes grammar tangible. If you don't have official Montessori grammar symbols, you can easily make them from construction paper or cardstock. The colors and sizes matter because they encode relationships: all noun-family words are triangles, all verb-family words are circles. This system helps children see patterns in language structure.

title: Introduction to the Bead Frame — Static Addition
description: Students are introduced to the large bead frame (Montessori abacus) as a new tool for addition. They learn how each row represents a place value and practice 'static' addition (no carrying) with 4-digit numbers.
instructions:
1. Present the large bead frame. Explain that each row is a place value.
2. Show how to read numbers on the bead frame.
3. Demonstrate building a number by sliding beads.
4. Show how to add two numbers without carrying (static addition).
5. Practice 5 static addition problems.
6. Record each problem on paper using the bead frame paper.

slides.heading: The Bead Frame
slides.subheading: A New Tool for Big Addition
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the title slide for our math adventure today! We're going to learn about a super cool tool called the bead frame, which is like a special abacus that helps us add really big numbers. Get ready to become addition superstars!

items: Large bead frame (units, tens, hundreds, thousands rows — 10 beads each)
slides.setup_instructions: Place the bead frame flat on the mat. All beads should be pushed to the right (showing zero). Have recording paper ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our math tools ready! We need the big bead frame – see all those rows of beads? We also need the special paper and a pencil to write down our answers. Make sure the bead frame is flat on the mat with all the beads pushed to the side, like a fresh start!

slides.text: Present the bead frame: 'This is the bead frame — a powerful calculator that mathematicians have used for thousands of years. Each row has 10 beads.' Point to each row: 'Bottom row = units (green). Next = tens (blue). Next = hundreds (red). Top = thousands (green). Does this color pattern remind you of anything?' (The stamp game!)
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us our amazing bead frame! Think of each row as a special spot for numbers. The bottom row is for the ones, the next row up is for the tens, then hundreds, and the very top row is for thousands – these are the big numbers! Doesn't that remind you of the stamp game colors?

slides.text: Show how to build a number: 'Let's build 2,341.' Slide 2 thousand beads left, 3 hundred beads left, 4 ten beads left, 1 unit bead left. 'Read it with me: two thousand, three hundred, forty-one.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's learn how to build a number on our bead frame. We're going to build 2,341. Watch how I slide two beads in the thousands row, three in the hundreds, four in the tens, and one in the ones. Now we can read it together: two thousand, three hundred, forty-one!

slides.text: Demonstrate static addition: 'Now let's add 2,341 + 1,235.' The first number is already on the frame. 'For the second number, we slide MORE beads: 1 more thousand, 2 more hundreds, 3 more tens, 5 more units.' Count the beads in each row: '3 thousands, 5 hundreds, 7 tens, 6 units = 3,576!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the magic happens – adding numbers! We already have 2,341 on the frame. To add 1,235, we just slide a few more beads. We add one more thousand, two more hundreds, three more tens, and five more ones. Now, let's count them all up – wow, we have 3,576!

slides.text: Show how to record on paper: write the problem vertically, work it out on the bead frame, record the answer. 'The bead frame helps us SEE the math, and the paper helps us REMEMBER the math.'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we add on the bead frame, it's super important to write it down so we don't forget. We'll write the problem on our paper, just like we did before, then use the bead frame to find the answer, and finally write that answer down too. The bead frame helps us see the math, and the paper helps us remember it!

slides.prompt:
Solve these addition problems on the bead frame. Record each one on paper:
1. 1,234 + 2,345 = ?
2. 3,012 + 1,456 = ?
3. 2,222 + 1,111 = ?
4. 4,130 + 3,521 = ?
5. 1,001 + 2,342 = ?
Remember: build the first number, then slide more beads for the second number.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to practice! Now it's your turn to be the math whiz. You'll build the first number on your bead frame, then slide the beads for the second number, and count up the total. Remember to write down each problem and its answer on your paper. You've got this!

slides.text: The bead frame lets you add numbers in the thousands quickly and accurately. But what happens when a row has MORE than 10 beads? We'll find out next time — that's called 'carrying' or 'dynamic addition.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build any 4-digit number on the bead frame? Can they add two 4-digit numbers when no carrying is needed? Can they record the problems on paper?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did an amazing job using the bead frame today to add big numbers! You built numbers and solved addition problems like a pro. We learned how to add without any tricky "carrying" – but next time, we'll learn what happens when a row gets too full, which is pretty exciting too!

parent_notes: The bead frame (also called the Montessori abacus) is a step MORE abstract than the stamp game. With stamps, each unit is a separate tile. On the bead frame, beads represent quantities by position — this is closer to how our number system actually works. Static addition (no carrying) lets the child learn the TOOL before tackling the harder CONCEPT of exchanging/carrying. If you don't have a Montessori bead frame, you can use a standard 4-row abacus or even make one with pipe cleaners and pony beads (10 beads per row: green, blue, red, green). The recording paper has columns for each place value — you can make this by drawing vertical lines on paper and labeling columns Th, H, T, U.

title: States of Matter: Solid, Liquid, Gas
description: Connecting directly to the First Great Lesson's demonstrations about the laws of matter, students explore the three states of matter through hands-on experiments. They observe how matter changes state with temperature and record their observations scientifically.
instructions:
1. Connect to the Great Lesson: 'Remember how particles follow laws? One of those laws is about how particles behave at different temperatures.'
2. Present the three states of matter with examples.
3. Demonstrate each state with the particle model (children acting as particles).
4. Conduct the ice-water-steam experiment.
5. Have the child sort objects by state of matter.
6. Introduce the scientific observation journal.

slides.heading: States of Matter
slides.subheading: Solid, Liquid, Gas — The Three Forms of Everything
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is the title page for our super cool science adventure all about "States of Matter"! It tells us we're going to learn about solids, liquids, and gases, which are the three main ways everything in the whole universe can be. Think about your toys, your juice, and even the air you breathe – they're all made of this stuff!

items: Pot of water and heat source
Various solid objects (rock, wood block, coin)
slides.setup_instructions: Set up a safe area near the stove or hot plate. Have ice cubes ready. Inflate a balloon. Prepare the three-column sorting mat on a table.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our experiment ready! We'll need some ice cubes in a bowl – that's water frozen solid. Then we have a pot of water and a way to heat it up, like a stove, to make it change. We also have some solid things like a rock and a coin, and an inflated balloon, which is like air trapped inside. Lastly, we have a special mat with three sections for "Solid," "Liquid," and "Gas," and our science journal to write and draw in. Go grab everything with a grown-up's help!

slides.text: Connect to the First Great Lesson: 'When the universe was born, all matter was incredibly hot — just energy and particles flying everywhere. As things cooled down, particles began to slow down and clump together. This is the secret of the three states of matter: it's all about how FAST the particles are moving.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember when we learned about how everything started super hot and then cooled down? This step reminds us that matter – that's all the stuff in the universe – acts differently depending on how hot or cold it is. When things are really hot, the tiny little pieces that make up everything zoom around super fast, and when they cool down, they slow down and stick together more. This is the secret to why things can be solid, liquid, or gas!

slides.text: Particle dance: 'Let's BE particles! When I say SOLID, stand close together and vibrate in place — barely moving. When I say LIQUID, spread out a little and flow around slowly. When I say GAS, run around the room bouncing off everything!' Practice all three. 'Solids: particles packed tight. Liquids: particles sliding past each other. Gases: particles flying freely.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pretend we are those tiny little pieces, called particles! If I say "SOLID," you'll stand super close together and just wiggle a little bit, like you're packed in tight. If I say "LIQUID," you'll spread out just a bit and slide past each other, like water flowing. And if I say "GAS," you'll run all around the room, bouncing off the walls and everything, because you're super spread out and moving fast! Let's try it!

slides.text: The transformation experiment: Place ice cubes in a pot. 'This is water as a SOLID. The particles are locked in a crystal pattern.' Heat the pot slowly. 'Watch what happens as we add heat energy...' The ice melts. 'Now it's a LIQUID! The particles are moving faster, sliding around each other.' Continue heating until steam rises. 'Now it's a GAS! The particles have so much energy they're escaping into the air!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the magic happens! We're going to put our ice cubes, which are solid water, into the pot. As we gently heat them up, watch closely – the solid ice will start to melt into liquid water. Then, when we keep heating it, it will turn into steam, which is water as a gas! We're seeing water change from one state to another right before our eyes.

slides.text: Key question: 'Is the water GONE when it becomes steam? No! The same particles are still there — they're just moving so fast we can't see them. Hold a cold plate over the steam...' (Condensation forms.) 'Look — the gas is turning BACK into liquid! Matter can change states, but it doesn't disappear.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, when we saw the steam disappear, it looked like the water was gone, right? But it's not! The tiny water particles just got so much energy from the heat that they spread way out and turned into a gas. Now, if we hold something cold, like a plate, above the steam, we can see the gas particles slow down and turn back into little drops of liquid water – it's like magic happening in reverse!

slides.prompt:
1. Sort 10 items onto your three-column mat: which are solids, liquids, or gases?
2. In your science journal, draw the particle model for each state (dots close together, dots flowing, dots spread apart).
3. Write a paragraph explaining how water can be a solid, a liquid, AND a gas. What makes it change?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the scientist! First, look at all those different objects and decide if they are a solid, a liquid, or a gas, and put them in the right spot on your sorting mat. Then, open your science journal and draw what the particles look like when they are in a solid, a liquid, and a gas. Finally, write a little bit about how water can be all three – solid ice, liquid water, and steamy gas – and what makes it change!

slides.text: Everything in the universe is made of matter, and all matter exists as a solid, liquid, or gas depending on temperature. The particles never disappear — they just speed up or slow down. Next science lesson, we'll explore classification — how scientists organize all the different types of matter and living things.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and describe all three states of matter? Can they explain what causes matter to change states? Can they sort common substances by state?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You explored solids, liquids, and gases, and even saw how water can change from one to another just by heating or cooling it. You learned that even though things change form, the tiny particles that make them up never really disappear, they just move faster or slower. Next time, we'll learn how scientists sort and organize all the amazing things in the world!

parent_notes: This lesson directly extends the First Great Lesson — the laws that particles follow include the rules about states of matter. This connection is intentional: in Montessori elementary, EVERYTHING connects back to the Great Lessons. The 'particle dance' is a powerful kinesthetic model that helps children understand an invisible process. The ice-to-steam experiment should be done with real heat and real observation — this is real science, not a worksheet. Safety note: supervise the hot plate/stove carefully, but don't do it FOR the child. They should observe closely (with appropriate distance from steam). The science journal is launched here and will be used all year. Encourage detailed drawings with labels — scientific illustration is a real skill.

title: Cosmic Art: Painting the Big Bang
description: Inspired by the First Great Lesson, students create an expressive painting of the Big Bang using wet-on-wet watercolor technique. They learn about warm and cool colors while creating art that represents the birth of the universe.
instructions:
1. Discuss: 'What did you imagine when you heard the story of the Big Bang? What colors do you see?'
2. Introduce warm colors (red, orange, yellow) and cool colors (blue, purple, green).
3. Demonstrate wet-on-wet watercolor technique.
4. Guide the child through painting their interpretation of the Big Bang.
5. Allow free expression — there is no 'wrong' way to paint the universe.
6. Display and discuss the finished piece.

slides.heading: Cosmic Art
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our amazing art project! It tells us we're going to be making "Cosmic Art" and painting a picture of something super special called the Big Bang. It's like getting ready for a grand adventure in space!

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the workspace with newspaper. Tape watercolor paper to the surface so it doesn't buckle. Have water cups and paints ready. Pre-wet the paper lightly with the spray bottle.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our painting. We've got watercolor paints in lots of colors, special thick paper that can handle lots of water, brushes for painting, a cup for our water, paper towels for oopsies, a spray bottle to make the paper wet, and some newspaper to keep our table clean. There's even optional salt to make sparkly stars! Make sure you gather all these things with a grown-up's help so we're ready to create!

slides.text: Begin with discussion: 'Close your eyes. Think about the First Great Lesson. Imagine the Big Bang — that moment when everything in the universe exploded into being. What colors do you see? What shapes?' Let the child describe their mental image.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to use our imaginations, just like when we heard the story of the Big Bang! Close your eyes and picture that moment when everything began. What colors pop into your head? Are they bright and fiery, or dark and deep? Tell me what you see in your mind – there are no wrong answers!

slides.text: Introduce color theory: 'Artists use WARM colors (red, orange, yellow) for energy, fire, and explosions. They use COOL colors (blue, purple, green) for space, darkness, and calm.' Show each group. 'The Big Bang had BOTH — cool, dark space and warm, explosive energy.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn about special color families! We have "warm" colors like red, orange, and yellow – they feel energetic and exciting, like fire. Then we have "cool" colors like blue, purple, and green – they feel calm and deep, like the night sky. Our Big Bang had both kinds of colors, all mixed together in a giant explosion!

slides.text: Demonstrate wet-on-wet technique: 'First, we wet the entire paper with the spray bottle. Then we drop color onto the wet surface and watch it SPREAD — just like the universe spread out after the Big Bang!' Drop a warm color onto wet paper and show how it blooms. 'The paint follows its own laws, just like the particles in the universe.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to see some magic happen! The grown-up will show you how to spray your paper so it's nice and wet. Then, when you drop paint onto the wet paper, it will spread out all by itself, like the universe expanding after the Big Bang! It’s so cool to watch the colors flow and mix, almost like they have a mind of their own.

slides.text: Optional texture technique: 'Sprinkle salt on the wet paint — it creates a starburst effect that looks like stars forming.' Demonstrate on a corner of scrap paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super fun trick to make our painting look extra special! If you want to add stars to your universe, you can sprinkle a little bit of salt onto the wet paint. Watch as the salt makes tiny patterns, like little starbursts appearing in your colorful space! It’s a cool way to add texture and make your universe unique.

slides.prompt: Create your Big Bang painting! Start with dark cool colors for space, then add warm explosive colors for the Bang. Let the colors blend and flow. Try the salt technique for stars. There is no wrong way to paint the universe — your interpretation is unique, just like you are unique in the universe.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's your turn to paint the Big Bang! Start by putting down some of those cool, dark colors for space, and then add your warm, bright colors where the explosion happened. Let the colors swirl and blend together on the wet paper, just like the universe coming to life. And don't forget, you can try the salt trick for stars too – remember, your painting is your very own universe!

slides.text: Look at your painting. You used warm and cool colors to create a piece of cosmic art. Every artist sees the universe differently, and your painting is your own interpretation of the greatest event in history. Let it dry flat and we'll display it.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify warm and cool colors? Did they use the wet-on-wet technique? Can they explain what their painting represents?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at your amazing cosmic art! You used those warm and cool colors to show your idea of the Big Bang, and you used that special wet-on-wet painting trick! Every painting tells a different story, and yours is a special picture of the universe's beginning. We'll let it dry flat so we can show off your awesome creation!

parent_notes: Art in Montessori elementary is not 'craft time' — it's integrated with academic content. This lesson connects directly to the First Great Lesson, reinforcing the cosmic narrative through a different modality. The wet-on-wet watercolor technique is particularly appropriate because it mirrors the Great Lesson's themes: the paint 'follows laws' as it spreads on wet paper, just as particles follow laws. Don't direct the child's artistic choices — say 'What does YOUR Big Bang look like?' rather than 'Paint it like this.' The color theory instruction (warm/cool) is genuine art education that will be built upon all year. Display the finished painting prominently — it represents the beginning of their cosmic education journey.

title: Setting Up Our Learning Environment
description: Students take ownership of their learning space by organizing materials, creating a daily schedule, and establishing classroom routines. In Montessori elementary, children are responsible for maintaining their environment — this is practical life at a higher level.
instructions:
1. Tour the learning space together. Discuss what makes a good workspace.
2. Organize materials by subject area.
3. Create labels for shelves and containers.
4. Set up a daily schedule together.
5. Establish routines: how we start the day, how we transition, how we clean up.
6. Practice the routines.

slides.heading: Our Learning Environment
slides.subheading: Creating a Space That Works for Us
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our big project today! It's called "Our Learning Environment," and it means we're going to make our classroom a super special place that's just right for *you* to learn and explore. Think of it like making your bedroom perfect for playing your favorite games!

slides.setup_instructions: Have all learning materials gathered but NOT yet organized. This lesson is about the child helping to organize their own space. Have the blank schedule ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these cool things! We have labels and a label maker, which are like name tags for our stuff. We also have baskets and containers to hold things, a clock or timer to help us keep track of time, a blank schedule so we can plan our day, and markers and pencils for decorating. You'll need all of these to help make our learning space amazing!

slides.text: Begin with a tour: 'This is YOUR learning space. In Montessori, the environment belongs to the children, not the teacher. That means YOU get to help set it up, and YOU are responsible for keeping it organized. Let's walk through and decide where everything should go.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like going on a treasure hunt in our classroom! We're going to walk around and look at everything. The most important thing to remember is that this whole space is for you to use and enjoy, so we need to figure out the best spots for all our books, toys, and supplies to make it work perfectly for you.

slides.text: Sort materials by subject: 'Where should the math materials go? Where should the science supplies be? Where will we keep our journals?' Let the child make decisions. Guide gently: 'Heavy materials go on lower shelves. Things you use every day should be easy to reach.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun puzzle part! We need to sort all our learning materials, like the math blocks and the reading books, into different groups. Think about where it makes the most sense to keep things – maybe heavier stuff goes down low, and things you use a lot should be easy to reach, just like putting your favorite toys where you can grab them fast!

slides.text: Make labels together. The child writes (or types and prints) labels for each area: Math, Language, Science, Geography, History, Art, Reading Corner. Place labels on shelves and containers. 'Now you always know where to find AND return your materials.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we get to be super creative and make our space look official! We'll make special name tags, called labels, for all the shelves and boxes. You can help write or type them, and then we'll stick them on so we always know exactly where everything belongs, which makes tidying up way easier later.

slides.text: Create the daily schedule together: 'Lower Elementary students have a 3-hour work cycle. That means you work for 3 hours with breaks when YOU decide you need them. Let's plan how each day will flow.' Fill in the weekly schedule template together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to become the boss of our day! We're going to make a schedule together, like a plan for what we'll do each hour. In Montessori, you get to choose your work for a big chunk of time, so we'll figure out how your day can flow best, making sure you have time for everything you want to learn and do.

slides.prompt:
1. Finish organizing all materials into their labeled spaces.
2. Practice the morning routine: enter the space, check the schedule, choose your first work, get materials from the shelf, work at your table, return materials when done.
3. Practice cleanup: return all materials, wipe down surfaces, push in chairs, check that everything is in its labeled spot.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's put all our planning into action! First, we'll put all the materials away in their new, labeled homes. Then, we'll practice starting our day, like checking our schedule and choosing our first activity, and we'll also practice cleaning up super well so our space stays neat and tidy.

slides.text: You now have a beautiful, organized learning environment that YOU created. When you take care of your space, your space takes care of you — everything is easy to find, easy to use, and easy to put away.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate any material independently? Do they understand the daily routine? Can they clean up and reset the space without reminders?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what we did! You helped create a fantastic learning space that's all yours, and it's super organized now. You'll be able to find everything you need so easily, and putting things away will be a breeze. You totally rocked making this space work for you!

parent_notes: Practical Life in Lower Elementary looks very different from Primary. Instead of pouring and spooning, children take on real responsibility: organizing their space, managing their time, preparing food for the family, and contributing to the community. This first lesson establishes the child's OWNERSHIP of their learning environment. In a Montessori classroom, children choose their work, get their own materials, and return them — the environment is set up for independence. At home, this means your child's learning area should be organized, accessible, and THEIRS to maintain. Resist the urge to organize FOR them. The 3-hour work cycle is a hallmark of Montessori elementary — children need long, uninterrupted blocks to do deep work. The schedule you create together should reflect this. Trust the process: children who own their environment take better care of it.

title: Journal Writing: My Universe Story
description: Students write their first journal entry of the year, reflecting on the First Great Lesson. They practice paragraph structure (topic sentence, supporting details, closing sentence) while processing the cosmic story they have been immersed in.
instructions:
1. Review the First Great Lesson briefly — what do you remember?
2. Teach/review paragraph structure: topic sentence, 3+ detail sentences, closing sentence.
3. Model writing a paragraph together on chart paper.
4. Have the child plan their paragraph using a simple graphic organizer.
5. Child writes independently.
6. Revise together: check for capitals, periods, and paragraph structure.
7. Child writes a final draft in their journal.

slides.heading: Journal Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is the title of our writing activity! It's called "Journal Writing: My Universe Story," which means we're going to write in our special notebooks about the amazing story of how everything in the universe began. Get ready to share your thoughts!

items: Chart paper or whiteboard for modeling
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a simple graphic organizer: a circle at top (topic sentence), three lines in the middle (details), and a circle at bottom (closing). Have chart paper ready for modeling.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for writing! We need our writing journal, a pencil with an eraser in case we make a mistake, some chart paper or a whiteboard so I can show you how to write, a special paper called a graphic organizer to help us plan, and some colored pencils for drawing later. Make sure you have all these things nearby!

slides.text: Warm up: 'Close your eyes. Think back to the First Great Lesson. What do you remember? What was the most amazing part?' Let the child share freely for 2-3 minutes. This activates their thinking before writing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's get our brains warmed up! Close your eyes for a moment and think back to the First Great Lesson about the universe. What do you remember about how everything started? What part of the story was the most exciting or surprising to you? Just think about it for a couple of minutes, and then we'll share our ideas.

slides.text: Teach paragraph structure: 'A paragraph is like a hamburger. The top bun is your TOPIC SENTENCE — it tells the reader what you're writing about. The meat and toppings are your DETAIL SENTENCES — at least 3 facts or ideas. The bottom bun is your CLOSING SENTENCE — it wraps everything up.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is teaching us about paragraphs, which are like little building blocks for stories. Think of a paragraph like a yummy hamburger: the top bun is the first sentence that tells everyone what the whole paragraph is about, the juicy middle with the meat and toppings are the sentences that give more details, and the bottom bun is the last sentence that closes it all up neatly.

slides.text: Model together: Write a topic sentence on chart paper. 'The story of the universe begins with a big bang.' Ask the child for detail sentences. Write 3 together. Add a closing sentence. Read the whole paragraph aloud. 'See? That's a complete paragraph!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to practice writing a paragraph together! I'll write the first sentence on the chart paper that tells us what we're writing about, and then you'll help me think of at least three exciting details to add. After that, we'll write a closing sentence to finish it off, and then we'll read our whole paragraph together to see how great it sounds!

slides.text: Guide planning: 'Now it's your turn. Fill in the graphic organizer first — just notes, not full sentences. What's your topic sentence? What 3 details will you include? How will you end it?' Review their plan before they start writing.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's your turn to plan your own universe story paragraph! On this special paper, you'll write down the main idea for your first sentence, then jot down some quick notes for at least three details you want to share, and finally, think about how you want to end your paragraph. It's like drawing a map before you build something awesome!

slides.prompt:
Write your paragraph about the First Great Lesson in your journal. Remember:
- Topic sentence (what is this paragraph about?)
- At least 3 detail sentences (what happened? what did you learn?)
- Closing sentence (why does this matter?)
- Use your best handwriting (cursive if you've learned it)
- When finished, draw an illustration to go with your writing.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the author! In your journal, write your own paragraph all about the First Great Lesson, using the plan you just made. Remember to start with a sentence that tells what it's about, add at least three sentences with details, and finish with a closing sentence. When you're done writing, you can draw a cool picture to go with your story!

slides.text: Read your paragraph aloud. You just wrote a complete paragraph about the birth of the universe! Every great scientist and historian started by writing down what they observed and learned — that's exactly what you did today.
slides.mastery_check: Does the paragraph have a clear topic sentence, at least 3 supporting details, and a closing sentence? Are sentences capitalized and punctuated? Is the content accurate to the Great Lesson?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you did! You just wrote a whole paragraph about the beginning of the universe, all by yourself! You followed all the steps, just like real scientists do when they share their discoveries. Your paragraph has a clear beginning, middle, and end, and you remembered to use capitals and periods – that’s fantastic writing!

parent_notes: Writing in Montessori elementary is always connected to content the child has experienced — never isolated 'writing practice.' By writing about the First Great Lesson, the child processes the story more deeply AND practices paragraph structure. The graphic organizer (hamburger paragraph) is a scaffold that helps children organize their thoughts before writing. Don't skip the planning step — children who plan write better paragraphs. During the writing phase, resist correcting every error. Focus on CONTENT first (Did they say something meaningful?), then STRUCTURE (paragraph format), then MECHANICS (spelling, punctuation). If your child learned cursive in primary, encourage it here. If not, print is fine — cursive can be introduced later. The reading journal and writing journal are SEPARATE — one records reading responses, the other is for original writing.

title: Bead Frame Addition — Dynamic (With Carrying)
description: Students advance to dynamic addition on the bead frame, where a row exceeds 10 beads and must be exchanged (carried) to the next place value. This is the same concept as 'carrying' in traditional addition but made visible and concrete.
instructions:
1. Review static addition briefly.
2. Present a problem where units exceed 10 (e.g., 1,237 + 2,845).
3. Show what happens when a row has more than 10 beads.
4. Demonstrate the exchange: slide 10 beads back, slide 1 bead on the next row forward.
5. Practice with problems that require carrying in one column, then multiple columns.
6. Record all work on bead frame paper.

slides.heading: Dynamic Addition
slides.subheading: When Beads Overflow — Carrying on the Bead Frame
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is introducing us to a super cool way to add bigger numbers, called "Dynamic Addition"! See how it says "When Beads Overflow"? That means we're going to learn what to do when we have too many beads in one spot, and how they "carry" over to the next, just like when you have too many candies and have to share them!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the bead frame with all beads to the right (zero). Have recording paper ready. Write the first problem on paper before beginning.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, time to get our math tools ready! We need our big bead frame, which is like a special calculator with beads, and our recording paper and pencil so we can write down our work. Make sure all the beads on the frame are pushed to the right side, like they're all at zero, and have your grown-up help you write down the first problem we'll work on.

slides.text: Quick review: 'Last time we added numbers where every row stayed under 10 beads. But what if the units add up to MORE than 10? Let's find out.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we added numbers before and the beads never went past 10 in any row? Well, sometimes when we add, we get more than 10, and that's totally okay! This step is just a reminder that we're going to learn what to do when that happens, so get ready for some exciting math magic!

slides.text: Build the problem: 1,237 + 2,845. Build 1,237 on the bead frame first. Now add 2,845: 'Start with thousands: slide 2 more. We have 3 thousand beads. Hundreds: slide 8 more. We have 10 hundred beads... wait. We have ALL 10 beads in the hundreds row! We can't go past 10. What do we do?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to build our first big addition problem: 1,237 plus 2,845. First, let's slide the beads for 1,237. Now, we need to add 2,845, starting with the thousands. Uh oh! When we try to add the hundreds, we have 10 beads in that row – that's too many! What do we do when we have a full row?

slides.text: Demonstrate the exchange: 'When we have 10 beads in ANY row, we slide all 10 BACK to the right, and slide 1 bead forward on the NEXT row up. 10 hundreds = 1 thousand!' Slide 10 hundred beads back, slide 1 more thousand bead left. 'Now we have 4 thousands and 0 hundreds. Continue with tens and units — carry whenever you reach 10.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the super important part: "carrying"! When a row is full with 10 beads, we slide all 10 of those beads back to the right. Then, we slide just ONE bead over on the *next* row up – that's like trading 10 hundreds for 1 thousand! So, 10 hundreds become 1 thousand, and we have 0 hundreds left. We'll do this whenever any row gets full.

slides.text: Complete the problem together: Tens: 3 + 4 = 7 tens (no carrying). Units: 7 + 5 = 12 units. Exchange! 10 units back, 1 ten forward. Now 8 tens, 2 units. Final answer: 4,082. Record on paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's finish this problem! We already handled the thousands and hundreds. Now, for the tens, 3 + 4 is 7, and that's not too many, so we're good there. But for the units, 7 + 5 is 12 – that's more than 10! So, we slide 10 units back and slide 1 ten forward, leaving us with 2 units and 8 tens. Our final answer is 4,082, and we'll write that down!

slides.prompt:
Solve these dynamic addition problems on the bead frame. Record each on paper:
1. 2,456 + 1,378 = ?
2. 3,567 + 2,845 = ?
3. 1,999 + 1,111 = ?
4. 4,758 + 3,694 = ?
5. Create your own problem that requires carrying in at least 2 columns.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to be the math magician! Use your bead frame to solve these addition problems, and remember to "carry" when a row gets full. Slide the beads carefully, trade 10 for 1 when you need to, and write down your answers on the paper. You've got this – show me how you can make those beads overflow and carry!

slides.text: You can now add ANY two numbers on the bead frame, even when the beads overflow! This exchange — trading 10 of one for 1 of the next — is one of the most important ideas in mathematics. It's how our entire number system works.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform the exchange correctly (10 beads back, 1 bead forward on next row)? Can they complete multi-column carrying? Do they record accurately on paper?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You can now add any two numbers using the bead frame, even when the beads overflow and you have to carry them over. That special trick of trading 10 beads for 1 bead on the next row is a super important math idea that helps us add all sorts of numbers. You're becoming a math whiz!

parent_notes: Dynamic addition (carrying) is the same concept whether done with golden beads, stamp game, bead frame, or pencil and paper. The beauty of Montessori math is that by the time a child writes the algorithm on paper, they have already DONE the carrying with their hands dozens of times. They understand WHY we 'carry the 1' — because 10 units literally becomes 1 ten. The bead frame makes this visible: when you have 10 beads and slide them all back, then slide 1 forward on the next row, the child SEES the exchange happen. This kinesthetic understanding prevents the common confusion of 'just memorize the carrying procedure.' If your child struggles, go back to the stamp game for a few problems — stamps are more concrete because each unit is a separate piece. Then return to the bead frame.

title: The First Great Lesson: Formation of Earth (Part 2)
description: Continuing the First Great Lesson, this session focuses on how Earth formed, cooled, and developed its atmosphere, oceans, and land. Students work with the Timeline of the Universe to visualize the immense spans of time involved.
instructions:
1. Review Part 1: 'Last time, we heard about the Big Bang and the formation of stars. What do you remember?'
2. Continue the story: the formation of the solar system and Earth.
3. Use demonstrations: the volcano model and water experiments.
4. Introduce the Timeline of the Universe (wall chart).
5. Discuss the scale of time.
6. Follow-up research work.

slides.heading: The First Great Lesson, Part 2
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover of a super interesting book called "The First Great Lesson, Part 2"! It tells us the story of how our amazing planet, Earth, went from being a hot, fiery mess to becoming our home. Get ready for some amazing discoveries about our world!

items: Timeline of the Universe (wall chart or scroll)
Baking soda, vinegar, red food coloring (volcano)
slides.setup_instructions: Have the volcano demo prepared (baking soda in container on tray). Hang or unroll the Timeline of the Universe. Have clay ready for the Earth-building activity.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, here are the special things we'll need for our adventure today! We have the "Timeline of the Universe" to see how old everything is, baking soda and vinegar for a cool volcano surprise, some clay to build our own Earth, and a globe to see our planet. You'll need a grown-up to help you gather these, just like a scientist preparing for an experiment.

slides.text: Review: 'What do you remember from Part 1? Tell me the story so far.' Let the child retell: Big Bang, particles, laws of matter, stars forming, our Sun. 'Excellent. Today we continue the story — the most exciting part, because it's about OUR planet.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like checking in with our story! Remember how we learned about the Big Bang and stars forming? This step is asking you to tell me what you remember from that part.
